--- knitr: opts_chunk: comment: "" cache: true --- # Factors {#sec-factors} Factors in R are used to store **categorical variables** and therefore have many important uses in statistics / data science / machine learning. For example, factors can be used to store information on sex, race, diagnosis, treatment group, etc.

::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='Factors_cache/html/fig-factors_a3148f68acf71f03fb983eede742ae4f'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Factors in R - Best to read through this chapter first and then refer back to this figure](./R_factors.png){#fig-factors fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: If you are new to R and to factors, begin with the following introductory-level section. ## Factors (introductory) {#factorsintro} ::: callout-note Factors in R are a special type of vector. - Each element can take one value from a set known as the factor's **levels**. - A factor's levels are stored in a particular **order**, which affects how that factor is treated by some functions, e.g. in hypothesis testing, model fitting, visualization, etc. - You can specify whether or not the order of the levels defines a quantitative relationship such that level1 < level2, etc., in which case the factor is known as **ordered**. ::: You can create a factor by passing a numeric or character vector to `factor()` or to `as.factor()`. The difference between the two is that `as.factor()` does not accept any arguments while `factor()` does. Let's start with a character vector that includes three unique values - "a", "b", and "c": ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_611da8f5c6631b702146e8fb5469b6fb'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c("a", "c", "b", "b", "a", "a", "b", "c") x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "a" "c" "b" "b" "a" "a" "b" "c" ``` ::: ::: Assume that "a", "b", and "c" define three different groups and we want to convert this character vector to a factor. `as.factor()` and `factor()` without any arguments produce the same output: ### Create a factor ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_fcf8d602a20c5284fb2eeb688ab81e9f'} ```{.r .cell-code} xf <- factor(x) xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] a c b b a a b c Levels: a b c ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} class(xf) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "factor" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} xftoo <- as.factor(x) xftoo ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] a c b b a a b c Levels: a b c ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} class(xftoo) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "factor" ``` ::: ::: Notice how a factor is printed in the R console: - The elements are printed without double quotes around them, differentiating them from character vectors. - The factor levels are printed below the vector values. `table()` is a very useful function for factors - it gives the counts for each level: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_51493e64cefd3ab213302f3c1ed99b1a'} ```{.r .cell-code} table(xf) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` xf a b c 3 3 2 ``` ::: ::: Let's look at a different example. We define a factor to identify cases and controls: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_abd8bfa34d3d1af2ccd50e130927d129'} ```{.r .cell-code} g <- factor(c("case", "control", "control", "case", "control")) g ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] case control control case control Levels: case control ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note By default, the levels are ordered *alphabetically*. ::: ### Set the order of factor levels You can define the order of the factor levels with the `levels` argument of the `factor()` function. For example, the first factor level is used as the baseline in some statistical operations, e.g. `glm()`, in which case the "control" level should be first. Many plotting functions order categorical axes' labels using the level order. ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_59057396eeb2f8e21c97b33bab066e8f'} ```{.r .cell-code} g <- factor(c("case", "control", "control", "case", "control"), levels = c("control", "case")) g ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] case control control case control Levels: control case ``` ::: ::: The `levels` argument can include values not present in the input data vector. This may be used for example when some known categories are not present in your sample, but may be added in the future, or you want specifically to show they are absent in a table or a plot, etc. ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_a78703c4bde45d4be0719827dc40698c'} ```{.r .cell-code} g <- factor(c("Type I", "Type III", "Type III", "Type I"), levels = c("Type I", "Type II", "Type III")) g ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Type I Type III Type III Type I Levels: Type I Type II Type III ``` ::: ::: On the other hand, if the `levels` argument is specified and does not include one or more of the values present in the input data vector, the corresponding elements become `NA`: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_5d39aa5202a0fd39eebd27ff364dc369'} ```{.r .cell-code} g <- factor(c("case", "control", "undefined", "control", "case", "control", "undefined"), levels = c("control", "case")) g ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] case control control case control Levels: control case ``` ::: ::: ### Define level labels You can define level names or ***labels*** other than the values in the input vector using the `labels` argument: Assume you started with the following character vector: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_7c3ff4f1ee9c12486494131bd9a03e21'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c("female", "female", "male", "female", "male") ``` ::: You can attach different labels to each level rather than default to "female" and "male" by passing a character vector to the `labels` arguments: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_7587bf99ab654e975a14f1d2a9cdfc14'} ```{.r .cell-code} xf <- factor(x, labels = c("F", "M")) xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] F F M F M Levels: F M ``` ::: ::: The order of names in the `labels` argument must match the order of levels. In the above example, the levels default to `c("female", "male")` because they are sorted alphabetically if not specified. Otherwise, we can specify both the `levels` and `labels` arguments to define both order of levels and provide new labels: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_93309095d4ea2fa7a01dd469bb7c845b'} ```{.r .cell-code} xf <- factor(x, levels = c("male", "female"), labels = c("M", "F")) xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] F F M F M Levels: M F ``` ::: ::: ### Change level labels of existing factor We can change the labels of a factor object - using the `labels` argument of the `factor()` command in the same way we create a factor from a character or other vector - using the `levels()` command Start with a factor of two groups and change labels using the `factor()` command: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_0702ed44bbf15f493f007e2567c1266a'} ```{.r .cell-code} xf <- factor(c("GroupA", "GroupB", "GroupB", "GroupA")) xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] GroupA GroupB GroupB GroupA Levels: GroupA GroupB ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-13_97009fe947e925184c2ec6658f69ff76'} ```{.r .cell-code} xf <- factor(xf, labels = c("A", "B")) xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] A B B A Levels: A B ``` ::: ::: Start with the same factor and change labels using the `levels()` command. This is similar to using `colnames()` on a data.frame and is much faster than using `factor()` as above: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-14_14c5cb94a1c4dd1d5ae70ba976a99966'} ```{.r .cell-code} xf <- factor(c("GroupA", "GroupB", "GroupB", "GroupA")) levels(xf) <- c("A", "B") xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] A B B A Levels: A B ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-caution The `levels()` command changes the ***names*** of the levels. It ***cannot be used to change the order of levels***, which must be done using `factor()`. ::: ## Factors (advanced) ::: callout-note A factor is a vector A factor contains three crucial pieces of information: 1. The underlying **integer vector** 2. The **mapping of integers to labels** 3. Whether the factor is **ordered** ::: Let's unpack these. Begin with a simple factor: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-15_3a07e9db23545c7ca3b28c2a7373871d'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(c("female", "female", "female", "male", "male")) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] female female female male male Levels: female male ``` ::: ::: Internally, the command sees there are two distinct labels, female and male, and defaults to assigning integer numbers alphabetically, in this case female has been mapped to '1' and male to '2'. Printing a factor prints the vector of labels followed by the levels, i.e. the unique labels. ### The underlying **integer vector** Each level is assigned an integer. (Internally, this is the "data" that forms the elements of a factor vector). You don't see these integers unless you convert the factor to numeric (`as.numeric()`) or look at the (truncated) output of `str()`; ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-16_0c45ff9c5e3a875b2e99b44f6c18c528'} ```{.r .cell-code} as.numeric(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 1 1 2 2 ``` ::: ::: ### The **mapping of integers to labels** This defines which integer is mapped to which label, i.e. whether 1 is mapped to male or female. You can store the same information regardless which one you choose to call 1 and 2. To get the mapping you can use `levels()`. It prints the labels in order: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-17_1428018a52d18a94deaa38fed785e777'} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "female" "male" ``` ::: ::: Again, this means that female is mapped to 1 and male is mapped to 2. ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-18_354361976ff37f5a11974402e131f6cd'} ```{.r .cell-code} str(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Factor w/ 2 levels "female","male": 1 1 1 2 2 ``` ::: ::: The above tells you that x is a factor, it has two levels labeled as "female" and "male", in that order, i.e. female is level 1 and male is level 2. The last part shows that the first five elements (in this case the whole vector) consists of three elements of level 1 (female) followed by 2 elements of level 2 (male). #### Setting new level labels You can use the `levels()` command with an assignment to assign new labels to a factor (same syntax to how you use `rownames()` or `colnames()` to assign new row or column names to a matrix or data frame); ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-19_182bd84e1689ca13094ee59b8a3a67bf'} ```{.r .cell-code} xf <- factor(sample(c("patient_status_positive", "patient_status_negative"), size = 10, replace = TRUE), levels = c("patient_status_positive", "patient_status_negative")) xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] patient_status_positive patient_status_positive patient_status_negative [4] patient_status_negative patient_status_negative patient_status_positive [7] patient_status_negative patient_status_negative patient_status_positive [10] patient_status_negative Levels: patient_status_positive patient_status_negative ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-20_838d9ae85889f5f090b3576e728cd3d4'} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(xf) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "patient_status_positive" "patient_status_negative" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} levels(xf) <- c("positive", "negative") xf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] positive positive positive negative positive positive negative negative [9] negative negative Levels: positive negative ``` ::: ::: #### Defining the mapping of labels to integers If you want to define the mapping of labels to their integer representation (and not default to them sorted alphabetically), you use the `levels` arguments of the `factor()` function. The vector passed to the `levels` arguments must include at least all unique values passed to `factor()`, otherwise you will get `NA` values. Without defining `levels` they are assigned alphabetically: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-21_8791e7097a101703e2eeac4a5b89376f'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(c("alpha", "alpha", "gamma", "delta", "delta")) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] alpha alpha gamma delta delta Levels: alpha delta gamma ``` ::: ::: Define `levels`: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-22_ae4c56f1190a1c02b3a40bb1438c1b98'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(c("alpha", "alpha", "gamma", "delta", "delta"), levels = c("alpha", "gamma", "delta")) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] alpha alpha gamma delta delta Levels: alpha gamma delta ``` ::: ::: The `table` command has a number of useful applications, in it simplest form, it tabulates number of elements with each unique value found in a vector: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-23_8d97b7de62c3743cc6017cafb49d6b30'} ```{.r .cell-code} table(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x alpha gamma delta 2 1 2 ``` ::: ::: If you forget (or choose to exclude) a level, all occurrences are replaced by `NA`: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-24_62b6fdd65af0d6ec80cf870da4e92ebf'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(c("alpha", "alpha", "gamma", "delta", "delta"), levels = c("alpha", "gamma")) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] alpha alpha gamma Levels: alpha gamma ``` ::: ::: If you know that more levels exist, even if no examples are present in your sample, you can includes these extra levels: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-25_293120e751ebe4c6a8f72b06a2213dad'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(c("alpha", "alpha", "gamma", "delta", "delta"), levels = c("alpha", "beta", "gamma", "delta")) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] alpha alpha gamma delta delta Levels: alpha beta gamma delta ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-26_6ff669efec4f55402dea0f2d9f536be9'} ```{.r .cell-code} table(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x alpha beta gamma delta 2 0 1 2 ``` ::: ::: ### Is the factor **ordered** We looked at how you can define the order of levels using the `levels` argument in `factor()`, which affects the integer mapping to each label. This can affect how some applications treat the different levels. On top of the order of the mapping, you can further define if there is a *quantitative relationship* among levels of the form `level 1 < level 2 < ... < level n`. This, in turn, can affect how the factor is treated by some functions, like some functions that fit statistical models. ::: callout-note All factors' levels appear in some order or other. An **ordered factor** indicates that its levels have a quantitative relationship of the form `level 1 < level 2 < ... < level n`. ::: First an unordered factor: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-27_69545820bc065b7b85c43770d890e37c'} ```{.r .cell-code} dat <- sample(c("small", "medium", "large"), size = 10, replace = TRUE) x <- factor(dat) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] small small large large medium medium large medium small medium Levels: large medium small ``` ::: ::: To make the above into an ordered factor, we need to define the order of the levels with the `levels` arguments and also specify that it is ordered with the `ordered` argument: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-28_c5f655f644c81d7721c4b781178774a1'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(dat, levels = c("small", "medium", "large"), ordered = TRUE) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] small small large large medium medium large medium small medium Levels: small < medium < large ``` ::: ::: Note how the levels now include the less-than sign (`<`) between levels to indicate the ordering. ### Change order of levels or labels We've seen how to create a factor with defined order of levels and how to change level labels already. Because these are prone to serious accidents, let's look at them again, together. **To change the order of levels** of an existing factor use `factor()`: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-29_c982fee52842c7840d0fdfcd2b7be5b4'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(c("target", "target", "control", "control", "control")) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] target target control control control Levels: control target ``` ::: ::: Change the order so that target is first (i.e. corresponds to 1: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-30_c7fdedfbfed2156723199e5eecf711e2'} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- factor(x, levels = c("target", "control")) x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] target target control control control Levels: target control ``` ::: ::: **To change the labels of the levels** use `levels()`: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-31_12eadc698f6586102167704ad5455e27'} ```{.r .cell-code} x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] target target control control control Levels: target control ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} levels(x) <- c("hit", "decoy") x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] hit hit decoy decoy decoy Levels: hit decoy ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-caution Changing the levels of a factor with `levels()` does not change the internal integer representation but changes every element's label. ::: ### Fatal error to avoid Example scenario: You receive a dataset for classification where the outcome is a factor of 1s and 0s: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-32_0c18cbf6a011b6231e2a6dc9e3854654'} ```{.r .cell-code} outcome <- factor(c(1, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0)) outcome ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 1 0 0 0 1 0 Levels: 0 1 ``` ::: ::: Some classification procedures expect the first level to be the 'positive' outcome, so you decide to reorder the levels. You mistakenly use `levels()` instead of `factor(x, levels = c(...))` hoping to achieve this. You end up flipping all the outcome values. ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-33_38d52ac521b21e0db49bea9d652d8918'} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(outcome) <- c("1", "0") outcome ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 0 1 1 1 0 1 Levels: 1 0 ``` ::: ::: All zeros became ones and ones became zeros. Your model does the exact opposite of what you intended. ### Factor to numeric While it often makes sense to have factors with words for labels, they can be any character and that includes numbers (i.e. numbers which are treated as labels) ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-34_31dbc3a2e592c4c79f5ba872a7e03cf6'} ```{.r .cell-code} f <- factor(c(3, 7, 7, 9, 3, 3, 9)) f ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 7 7 9 3 3 9 Levels: 3 7 9 ``` ::: ::: This behaves just like any other factor with all the rules we learned above. There is a very easy trap to fall into, if you ever decide to convert such a factor to numeric. The first thing that usually comes to mind is to use `as.numeric()`. ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-35_1cd5c9f5892e7c8a44b6942fe188c10b'} ```{.r .cell-code} # !don't do this! as.numeric(f) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 2 3 1 1 3 ``` ::: ::: But! We already know this will return the integer index, it will not return the labels as numbers. By understanding the internal representation of the factor, i.e. that a factor is an integer vector indexing a set of labels, you can convert labels to numeric exactly by indexing the set of labels: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-36_5a1f3463c3bebe24b2c7959a61d639af'} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(f)[f] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "3" "7" "7" "9" "3" "3" "9" ``` ::: ::: The above suggests that used as an index within the brackets, `f` is coerced to integer, therefore to understand the above: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-37_caadd8fbb467c435d2e8ea6d1d3ebf7d'} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(f) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "3" "7" "9" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} levels(f)[as.integer(f)] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "3" "7" "7" "9" "3" "3" "9" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # same as levels(f)[f] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "3" "7" "7" "9" "3" "3" "9" ``` ::: ::: A different way around this that may be less confusing is to simply convert the factor to character and then to numeric: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-38_9fd1cb91044c9989f5217e287789771f'} ```{.r .cell-code} as.numeric(as.character(f)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 7 7 9 3 3 9 ``` ::: ::: ## Interactions On many different occasions we want to look at factor interactions, e.g. for visualization, statistical hypothesis testing, predictive modeling, etc. Some functions allow you to define factors that should be allowed to interact and take of the rest for you. To explicitly create a factor interaction, you can use the `interaction()` function: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-39_9a335528845c9937bfa64640d9913aae'} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(2022) dat <- data.frame( PID = 8001:8009, Sex = factor(sample(c("male", "female"), size = 9, replace = TRUE)), Group = factor(sample(c("A", "B"), size = 9, replace = TRUE)) ) dat ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` PID Sex Group 1 8001 female B 2 8002 male A 3 8003 female A 4 8004 male B 5 8005 male B 6 8006 female A 7 8007 female A 8 8008 male B 9 8009 female A ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='Factors_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-40_cae3fbbb0b809a11e73061ae9f86154f'} ```{.r .cell-code} dat["Sex_x_Group"] <- interaction(dat[["Sex"]], dat[["Group"]]) dat ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` PID Sex Group Sex_x_Group 1 8001 female B female.B 2 8002 male A male.A 3 8003 female A female.A 4 8004 male B male.B 5 8005 male B male.B 6 8006 female A female.A 7 8007 female A female.A 8 8008 male B male.B 9 8009 female A female.A ``` ::: ::: ## Summary ::: callout-note - Factors in R are essentially ***integer vectors with labels***. - A factor's internal integer values range from 1 to the number of levels, i.e. categories. - Each integer corresponds to a label. - **To set order of levels**: `factor(x, levels = levels_in_desired_order)` to order levels - **To change labels**: `levels(x) <- newlabels` or `factor(x, labels = newlabels)` ::: ::: callout-note To avoid confusion, do not use numbers as level labels, if possible. :::
